Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing adequate services, resulting in a large
number of youths going to the emergency department.
Investigation On 11/22/24 Complainant reported a concerning number of
youths from Vista Maria were dropped at local hospital
emergency departments within the last 48 hours. There is
concern the agency is not providing proper care and
programming to prevent the youth from needing care in the
emergency department.
Interviews:
Chief Administrator, Rights Officer, and Quality Manager
were contacted on 11/22/24 by email to obtain the names of
youth that were seen at a hospital from 11/19/24-11/22/24.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth A reported she attended school daily and had therapy 1-2
times per week. Youth A stated they did not do any activities on
her unit. After school they relaxed for a while, then had dinner,
chores, hygiene, and bedtime. Youth A stated there were no
group activities, games, art, or journaling. When asked if activities
were limited due to behavior issues, Youth A answered, “yes”.
Youth A reported when youth behavior was out of control, police
would be called. Youth A gave examples of out-of-control
behavior as youth fighting and hurting one another, suicidal
behavior, self-harming behavior, breaking windows and doors.
Staff would call for the unit to clear. Additional staff would
respond to try to help. Staff tried to stop kids by talking to them,
removing objects, separating youth, deescalating, and
redirecting. If none of that worked, police may be called. Police
would then take the youth to the hospital. The hospital usually
2

just sent them back. Staff always went to the hospital to stay with
youth.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth B reported other than attending school, they did not do
much on her unit. Sometimes they watched television or played
games. But there were not many scheduled group activities.
Youth B stated Journey To Success (JTS) staff used to go to their
unit all the time. JTS would do group activities and independent
livings skills, but that no longer happened. Youth B stated they
recently had a lot of downtime. Youth B acknowledged that these
activities may not happen because there were always issues on
her unit. Youth B stated some peers were able to go to another
unit for events, while others on wing restriction were not allowed
to participate. Youth B wanted to have more activities such as
music/dance, karaoke, gym/exercise, and arts/crafts. Youth B
stated police were called to the facility when staff were unable to
calm down a youth that was attacking people, harming
themselves, swallowing items, or suicidal. Staff would talk with
kids and try to help them by giving prompts and trying to redirect,
before calling the police to assist. If the police came to campus,
they usually took the youth to the hospital for an evaluation. Staff
always went to the hospital with youth.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth C stated they had school daily and therapy 1-2 times per
week. Youth C reported they had activities through JTS, but that
no longer happened. Staff also tried to have groups daily, but not
everyone wanted to participate. There were some arts, crafts,
and games. However, they did not practice in independent living
skills and did not go outside, or off campus for outings. Youth C
reported that police would be called to campus if youth were
escalated, and staff could not calm them down. Youth C stated
staff tried to deescalate youth by talking to them and getting them
to focus on other things. But when they were unsuccessful, the
police would pick the youth up and take them to the hospital for
an evaluation. Usually, the hospital would send the youth right
back without doing anything. Staff always sat with youth at the
hospital.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/6/24.
Youth D reported their typical day consisted of school, down-time,
therapy or other appointments, dinner, activities, phone calls, and
bedtime. Youth D reported they could not always follow the
schedule as Youth C was very disruptive and caused problems
that pulled staff away from doing activities. Youth D stated that
3

Youth C attacked people, started fights, and destroyed items on
the unit. Staff intervened by talking to youth, redirecting, calling
the unit to clear and separating youth. If someone was being very
violent, the police may be called. The police sometimes arrive
and speak to youth and other times they took youth to the
hospital. If youth went to the hospital, staff followed and stayed
with the youth until discharge.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24
and 1/17/24. Youth E reported they no longer had activities
through JTS. Youth really enjoyed the JTS program because they
would help youth with independent living skills such as cooking.
Youth E stated they did not have many activities due to two youth
on the wing that always caused problems. Youth E reported they
were sometimes able to go to the boutique on campus to shop,
as a reward. Other youth that were on wing restriction were not
able to do that. Youth E stated she wanted to go to the gym more
often, but peers made that difficult. Youth E stated that police
were not called to campus that often. Staff would only call if they
had tried to work with youth that were very physically aggressive
but had been unsuccessful at calming them down. Youth E stated
that staff would speak with youth, redirect them and try to get
them to focus on something different. If police came to campus,
they typically transported the youth to the hospital for an
evaluation. In Youth E’s experience, the hospital did not take
youth seriously and immediately discharged them. Youth E
recalled a time that she was sent there for suicidal thoughts.
Youth E told hospital staff she planned to kill herself and they
sent her back to the facility without being evaluated. The facility
put her on an increased supervision plan and took the situation
more seriously than the hospital.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face on 12/17/24 at the facility.
Youth F stated she did not like being at the facility as staff were
always correcting her and trying to make her do things that she
did not feel like doing. Youth F clarified that she meant
schoolwork, cleaning her room and participating in groups. Youth
F stated they participated in some activities such as cooking, ‘my
life/my choice’, movies, gym time, games, and crafts. Youth F
stated that she recently worked with a peer to write an essay
about other things they should be able to do while at the facility.
Youth F presented several ideas during the interview. Youth F
stated they were sometimes unable to do activities when peers
on the unit were acting out and require staff intervention. Youth F
said that staff would talk with youth when they had problems and
try to deescalate and redirect them. Police were not often called
4

to the building, but if they were, it was usually to help transport a
youth safely to the hospital when their behavior was out of
control. After the interview, Rights Officer was informed of Youth
F’s essay. Rights Officer indicated Youth F may be part of their
student panel to help plan activities.
Youth G was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth G stated she felt the program was helpful and she did not
have any concerns. Youth G stated she participates in several
activities every day, including art, dance, games, group work,
movies, and reading. Youth G reported she also attended therapy
weekly. Youth G felt that they had very good staff at the facility.
Youth G did not have any experience with the police coming to
the building or youth going to the hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 1 stated everything was going well at the facility. Some of
the youth had significant behavioral issues that required the use
of additional staff support. The youth’s therapist or clinical director
would be called to the unit to assist as needed. If youth were
highly escalated and physically assaulting others, the police may
be called to the unit. Police would then transport the youth to the
hospital for evaluation. Staff would also go to the hospital with
youth. Staff 1 stated some of the youth on wing restriction had too
much downtime. The youth needed more group activities and
bonding activities that would help them connect with one another
and have fewer issues. Otherwise, their daily schedule typically
included school, phone calls, chores, dinner, and some down
time before bed. There was also someone that came in
occasionally to run group activities.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 2 stated some youth in the program were bored, due to
privileges being taken away for behavior. Staff did the best they
could to keep youth busy and provide them with support.
However, not all of the youth wanted to participate or listen to
staff. Staff 2 stated when youth acted out, there were not many
consequences to discourage them from acting out again later.
Staff 2 stated youth behavior that warranted intervention included
attacking staff, attacking one another, breaking items, fighting, or
attempting to AWOL. Staff 2 stated youth received a lot of
support, but they did not see the big picture, and did not use the
support available to them. Staff 2 did not have any contact with
police on campus and has not gone to the hospital with youth.
However, Staff 2’s understanding was that a team leader or
5

supervisor would call the police for assistance if staff were unable
to calm a youth and people were being injured.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/24.
Staff 3 stated a typical day for youth was to get up and take care
of hygiene before school, then after school they were busy doing
activities. Activities include games, arts/crafts, painting,
journaling, talking, basketball, walks, and group activities. Staff 3
was relatively new and had not experienced JTS. Staff 3 stated
that they tried to involve all youth, but some do not cooperate and
refuse to participate. Some youth behavior also hindered the
other youth from being able to participate organized activities.
Staff 3 felt that staff were able to deescalate youth effectively
through conversation and redirection. Staff 3 had not been
involved in any situations that involved the police or hospital.
However, their understanding was that supervisors would contact
the police for assistance if a youth was uncontrollably physical
and harming people, after failed attempts by staff to redirect and
deescalate.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/24.
Staff 4 reported the youth had a daily schedule, depending on if it
was a school day. After school and on weekends, youth would
paint/draw, play games, attend group therapy, motivational
activities, talk, and complete school activities on their computers
if needed. Staff 4 stated they believed staff were good at
discussing emotions and working together to make situations
better. Prior to calling the police, staff would talk with the girls, try
to get them calm, discuss solutions, do activities, do physical
activity to work energy out, and try to get them grounded and take
their mind off what they are mad about. The police would only be
called to campus if a youth was physically violent with staff, and
they were unsuccessful at deescalating them. A team leader or
supervisor would make that decision. The police would come on-
site, talk with the youth, and sometimes escort them to the
hospital. Staff would go to the hospital as well. But youth would
typically return to the facility right away.
Chief Administrator contacted DCWL via email on 12/20/24,
outlining activities planned for youth during their holiday break
from school. Activities included Science Technology Engineering
Math (STEM) activities, basketball, holiday party, Lego activities,
movies, and a content creator workshop.
Rights Officer was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/15/25. Rights Officer reported the facility was partnering with
6

Wayne County Community Mental Health to complete on-site
screenings for Wayne MDHHS youth, to determine if they are in
need of short-term hospitalization. On 1/21/25 Rights Officer
clarified via email that JTS was a program within Vista Maria that
organized events such as groups and dances, where instructors
were brought to campus. Recently they had a hair show and a
family movie day for the youth. Dream Realized through
Education/Empowerment and Mentoring (DREAM) was a group
that was part of JTS that also offers group activities to youth on
campus. Heart Warmers was a spiritual group that youth could
participate in on Sundays. Rights Officer confirmed that all of
these groups remain active on campus.
Quality Manager was contacted via email on 1/23/25 regarding
the plans to revamp services on campus. Quality Manager
reported there was a work group developed by the Activities &
Academic Support Manager. The work group was reviewing
current activities and creating new programming activities to
engage the youth. Previously the facility contracted with outside
partners for activities. There was also a restructured client
advisory board, similar to a student council, to provide youth with
more of a voice in decisions that were made. Youth would be
able to bring any issues, concerns, wishes, requests to the group
for discussion and decision making.
Activities & Academic Support Manager (AASM) was
contacted via email on 1/23/25. AASM outlined the following
items available to youth on campus: afterschool activities include
but are not limited to, expressive therapies such as yoga, dance
movement therapy, music therapy, art therapy, physical activity
and nutritional health education. Academic mentoring and
tutoring are supported through the DREAM program as it
connects each youth with mentors who are successful in their
career paths and provide supports by focusing on their education
and future career goals. In addition, the activity team provides
programing that creates a safe environment to strengthen coping
skills, promote social connections, and support healthy self-
esteem and confidence through creative self-care
strategies. Lastly, the Transition to Independence Process (TIP)
model, supports the youth in areas of education, employment,
social skills, relationships and health, and life skills.
Therapist 1 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 1
was assigned to Youth C. Therapist 1 reported that youth were
offered activities such as games, art, gym, dance class, and
cooking class. Therapist 1 reported that youth may have
7

indicated that they were not doing as many activities lately, but
this was due to some programs being revamped. Some activities
may be restricted if the youth was physically aggressive. For
example, instead of using colored pencils that may be sharp, a
youth could be given crayons to draw. Youth also attended
individual and family therapy, and occupational therapy. In
therapy they worked on triggers and warning signs, coping skills,
thinking/feeling, and problem solving. Youth C was receiving
cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Youth C engaged in therapy
and was benefiting from it. Regarding hospitalization and police
contact, Therapist 1 reported that youth may be escorted to the
hospital by police if they had continued escalated physical
aggression, self-harming, or suicidal behavior that staff were
unable to reduce after multiple attempts to help the youth self-
regulate. The clinical supervisor and clinical director must make
the determination if assistance was to be called. Therapist 1 also
reported that the facility had begun a partnership with Wayne
County CMH, where CMH staff would complete on-site
assessments to determine if a youth was eligible for short term
hospitalization.
Therapist 2 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 2
was assigned to Youth A. Therapist 2 reported that youth at the
facility were offered therapy, psychiatrist appointments,
occupational therapy, DREAM, life skills, leadership skills, and
afterschool activities such as sports, art, and dance. Youth attend
therapy twice per week on a flexible schedule that worked best
for the youth. Youth A declined to attend therapy at times, and
when she attended, she was not engaged. Therapist 2 stated that
Youth A was not interested in working on anything
therapeutically. Regarding police and hospital services, youth
would be sent to the hospital when there was a suicide attempt or
AWOL. Youth may also be sent if they were highly aggressive
toward others, and staff had been unsuccessful at calming them
down. The police may be called to safely escort youth to the
hospital upon approval by the clinical supervisor and director.
Therapist 2 noted that the facility was also working with Wayne
County CMH, as they would come on site to complete
assessments for youth, rather than sending the youth to the
hospital.
Therapist 3 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 3
reported that youth participated in therapy 1-2 times per week,
depending on their program. Youth also attended group therapy,
expressive therapies, recreational therapy through Journey to
Success (JTS). JTS includes Science Technology Education
8

Math (STEM) activities, mentoring and educational tutoring.
Youth also received occupational therapy, psychiatric, medical,
and family engagement services. While on their unit youth were
able to play games, participate in art, watch television, and
participate in groups. Regarding police or hospital involvement,
their services might be needed if a youth was highly escalated to
an extent that it was a safety concern, and they were unable to
regulate themselves or be deescalated. Sometimes physical
intervention could be used, but that was not always safe,
especially with a youth that was self-harming or physically
aggressive. The unit manager, clinical director or head consulting
psychiatrist made the determination if youth should be sent to the
hospital. Therapist 3 stated the facility began working with Wayne
County Community Mental Health to complete assessments at
the facility rather than visiting the hospital. Therapist 3 did not
have any experience with this service.
Therapist 4 was interviewed by phone on 1/24/25. Therapist 4
stated that youth on campus participated in individual therapy,
group work, JTS activities, DREAM program, Alcoholics
Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous, structured activities with
volunteer groups, occupational therapy, religious services, and
receive support from youth counselors. JTS had pro-social life
skills, games, yoga, dance, sports and art. DREAM offered life
skills, vocational training, exercise and mentorship. On the unit,
youth were able to participate in art, games, movies, crafts,
activities in the courtyard, and go on outings in the community.
These activities could be modified at times, due to youth
behavioral or safety issues. Therapist 4 stated that youth
received at least one hour of therapy per week, which may be
broken up into smaller sessions, depending on the youth.
Regarding police or hospital involvement, Therapist 4 stated that
police may be called to campus if youth had violent behaviors
and attacked staff or peers. Police would not be called until after
staff had made several efforts to deescalate the youth. A
supervisor, clinical director and the psychiatrist would determine
when police would be called to campus. Generally, this decision
would be made when a youth needed to be evaluated, but staff
did not feel they could safely transport the youth. Therapist 4
stated that she had some experience with the new process of
having Wayne County Community Mental Health complete an
assessment on-site, in lieu of going to the hospital. The
assessment was well done and determined the youth needed
inpatient hospitalization. However, there was not a placement
available. The service was helpful, but not as helpful as they
hoped.
9

Documents Reviewed:
• Vista Maria Program Statement updated 3/22/2024: Direct
Program Services: “weekly individual therapy, monthly
family and group therapy, sensory integration approaches,
expressive therapies, group counseling focused on
intervention, non-violent crisis interventions approaches,
community outings, daily recreation, after-school activities,
nursing services, mentoring, life skills education, family
visitation and phone call opportunities, transportation to
home visits when appropriate, family engagement events,
and aftercare services for six months after discharge.
Contracted services include on-campus education,
psychiatric and psychological evaluations, medical, optical,
and dental examinations.”
• “Youth log of daily expectations”: Staff must indicate if
youth met expected behavior standards for the following
activities: social skills, peer interaction, school/study time,
personal care, group participation, recreation participation,
room care/chores, healthy eating, appropriate dress,
effective coping skills, safe behavior/transport.
• ‘Emergency Psychiatric Care” policy dated July 2014.
• If client is in imminent danger of harming herself or
others, supervisor/team leader/staff contacts 911.
• If the situation is serious but there is no imminent
danger, arrange for staff or private ambulance
transport to appropriate psychiatric crisis
assessment center.
• Staff should not transport an uncontrollable client. If
the situation requires it, the supervisor should call
911 for assistance.
• “Police on Campus” policy dated March 2021:
• When a situation arises that threatens the health,
safety, and welfare of our clients or staff and that is
beyond our ability to control, the police department
should be contacted for assistance.
• The shift supervisor or designated will contact the
police via 911.
• Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that
had schedule activities documented such as daily group,
daily phone calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS,
“Chicktime” with volunteer group, Vista Maria reads (Book
Ladies), Lost Voices Concert, town hall meeting, Boots &
Bites with Lace Up Detroit, Pet Therapy, holiday events
with Abhi Shah Foundation, holiday decorating, and youth
health fair.
10

• A review of MiSACWIS incident reports for the facility was
completed to confirm the youth that visited the hospital
from 11/19-24-11/22/24: Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and
Youth E.
• Case record review for Youth A:
• Youth A was placed at the facility on 6/12/24.
• Incident report dated 11/19/24- Around 12:00AM
Youth A was kicking walls, doors and destroying the
unit. Staff attempted to verbally deescalate. Staff
removed youth’s shoes to keep her from kicking.
Youth A began banging on the television. Youth A
was verbally redirected. Youth A stated she wanted
to police called to take her to the emergency room.
Staff continued to try to redirect and deescalate.
Staff observed an object in youth’s hand. Youth
refused to give it to staff. Youth threatened to stab
staff if they touched her. Youth A’s aggressive
behavior continued as she began breaking items to
use as a weapon. Staff continued talking with youth
and had the therapist on-site to assist. Youth A
began to self-harm. Police were called at 12:42AM
to escort Youth A to the hospital. Staff followed to
the hospital. When they arrived, Youth A stated she
was fine and just wanted to go for a car ride.
• Hospital discharge summary dated 11/19/24
indicated conduct disorder and aggression.
• Updated Service Plan dated 11/4/24: Youth A
continues to focus on stabilizing her mental health
and behaviors. Youth A has received numerous
incident reports regarding her behaviors. Youth A
has been verbally aggressive, threatened staff and
residents, destroyed property, refused to follow
directions, and self-harmed. There is a
proactive/reactive safety plan in place to address
expectations, behavioral consequences, and crisis
management.
• Therapist 2 provided documentation to verify that
Youth A attended the majority of weekly therapy
sessions. Youth A was offered therapy several days
per week and refused some sessions.
• Case record review for Youth B:
• Youth B was placed at the facility on 09/06/24.
• Incident report dated 11/19/24, 7:20AM- Youth B hit
staff in the face with a closed fist. Youth B chased
several staff around the wing attempting to assault
them. Therapist 1 was called to the unit to speak
11

with Youth B. Youth B would not deescalate. Police
were called as Youth B continued to assault staff. At
7:51AM police escorted Youth B to the hospital;
staff followed.
• Hospital discharge summary 11/19/24- noted
behavioral health concern.
• Updated Service Plan dated 12/5/24- Youth B could
not attend court due to unsafe behavior, suicidal
ideation, and unwillingness to work with staff. Vista
Maria continues to be safest placement able to
meet her needs. Staff work with Youth B on building
healthy relationships with staff and peers. Youth B
attends individual and group therapy but does not
engage in therapy and services offered to her.
Youth B is able to process incidents after the fact
but struggles when overstimulated or triggered.
Staff use discussion, calming room, stress
reduction, 5 methods of grounding techniques and
coping skills. Youth B has access to multiple
therapies, JTS, support staff, recreation, mentoring,
and psychiatric care.
• Therapist 5 provided documentation to verify that
Youth B attended therapy consistently on a weekly
basis.
• Case record review for Youth C:
• Youth C was placed at the facility on 8/14/24.
• Incident report dated 11/19/24- Youth C was in a
verbal altercation with a peer and threatened to
assault peer. Staff separated the two youth and
tried to redirect the behaviors. Youth C attempted to
leave the unit. Youth C had a pen and tried to use it
as a weapon. Youth C refused to give staff the pen.
Youth C grabbed a chair and began banging it on
the wall and floor. Therapist 3 spoke with Youth C,
but the youth threatened to stab the therapist. Youth
C forced her way through the wing door and
attempted to assault a peer. Staff blocked the
assault. Police arrived at the facility and escorted
Youth C to the hospital.
• Hospital discharge summary dated 11/19/24
indicated Youth C had aggressive behavior-
conduct disorder.
• Updates Service Plan dated 11/12/24. Youth C has
ongoing behavioral concerns, struggles with
emotional regulation and relationships. Youth C has
stolen contraband from the hospital, including a
12

scalpel. Youth C has been searched by metal
detectors when leaving the hospital. Youth C is
involved in frequent verbal altercations, hitting staff,
threatening to stab people, threatening to murder
people, throwing items, kicking doors, and breaking
windows. Youth C was diagnosed with PTSD.
Youth C is monitored for emotional regulation, self-
harm, and homicidal ideation. Youth C participates
in therapy and treatment including discussion of
short-term rewards and long-term consequences,
and increased privileges for good behavior. Youth C
participates in JTS programs, school
accommodations, mentoring, tutoring, self-care,
group and individual therapy. Youth C has
supportive contact with family and other support
persons.
• Therapist 1 provided documentation to verify that
Youth C attended weekly therapy consistently.
• Case record for Youth E:
• Youth E was placed at the facility on 7/24/24.
• Incident report dated 11/22/24, 7:15AM- Youth E
attempted to lock herself in the bathroom, but staff
intervened and used verbal de-escalation. Youth E
became frustrated and began kicking the wall.
Youth E pulled a screw out of the wall and began
scratching her wrists. Staff utilized verbal de-
escalation. Youth E gave the screw to staff. Youth E
then began self-harming with one of the lenses from
her glasses. Staff used verbal techniques to no
avail. Youth E attempted to swallow the lense. A
team leader entered the unit and was able to
retrieve the item from Youth E. Youth E asked to go
to the hospital as she was feeling suicidal. A
supervisor and clinical director were contacted.
Police were called and escorted Youth E to the
hospital, with staff following. Prior to returning to the
facility, Youth E’s room was cleared out to remove
any objects that could be used for self-harm. Youth
E was placed on self-harm observations.
• Updated Service Plan dated 12/16/24. Youth E
continues to struggle with thoughts of self-harm and
was recently taken to the emergency room for an
evaluation. Youth E has a history of substance use
and mental health concerns. Behavior management
while at the facility shall be positive and consistent
messaging, based on child’s needs. Youth E shall
13

be disciplined with verbal redirection, simple and
kind commands, loss of electronics and privileges.
Youth E receives monthly medication reviews,
worker phone and in-person contact as needed.
Youth E is not allowed to have shoelaces, sharp
objects, or objects that can be used to inflict harm.
Youth E can call the crisis hotline if they have any
ideations of self-harm. Youth E did not have any
concerns about eating or sleeping and reported
completing chores and making friends. This
continues to be the least restrictive setting for Youth
E.
• Therapist 1 provided documentation to verify that
Youth E has attended weekly therapy consistently.

Description recreational activities designed to meet the residents’ needs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing sufficient activities for youth.
Investigation During interviews, youth and staff reported there were several
activities available to youth in the program However, Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth F, Staff 1, Staff 2
and Staff 3 reported that activities did not always occur. Youth
and staff indicated there was increased acting out behavior when
activities did not occur, or when youth were placed on wing
restriction from activities. Youth and staff reported concerns that
the agency’s behavior management/reward system was not
effective. Youth and staff reported concerns that staff spend too
much time deescalating certain youth and therefore not
completing activities with other youth.
14

During interviews Youth C reported they do not have
opportunities to participate in outdoor activities.
Activities & Academic Support Manager provided
documentation of several indoor activities made available for
youth. However, no outdoor activities were identified.
During a call on 2/6/25, Chief Administrator and Quality
Manager reported that youth participate in outdoor activity when
the weather permits. However, they were unsure if there was a
schedule of outdoor activities. They were asked to provide
documentation to show that youth were participating in outdoor
activity on a regular basis. In subsequent emails on 2/10/25 and
2/14/25, Quality Manager reported they did not have any
documentation to verify this request.
Documents Reviewed:
Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily phone
calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime” with volunteer
group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost Voices Concert,
town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace Up Detroit, Pet
Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah Foundation, holiday
decorating, and youth health fair.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as youth reported being
unable to participate in activities due to peer behavior, or not
having any activities available to them while on wing restriction.
Youth also reported they are not able to engage in outdoor activity
and the agency did not have any documentation to verify outdoor
activities occur with youth.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was offered regarding youth behavior on units that
disrupt the daily activities. When disruptive behavior is ongoing
and prohibiting other youth from their daily activities, efforts should
be made to continue activities with youth in another area, away
from the disruption. Not only would this be a positive step for the
other youth, but it would also take away the acting out youth’s
power to control the daily activity of the unit. Additionally, for youth
placed on restriction that are missing activities, staff should
continue to focus on encouraging the youth to reduce behaviors in
order to re-join the group. This may help alleviate the youth’s
feeling that wing restriction is never ending. Lastly, inclusion of
ideas from some restricted youth in the client advisory board
would be a great way to determine some activities that restricted

youth may be interested in, to help them increase engagement in
the program.
Conclusion Violation Established
